body:
> PSVersion                      7.1.4

Can you reproduce with latest _daily_ PowerShell 7.2 build?
Can you please remind me where to get it? I keep forgetting...

From: Stéphane BARIZIEN ***@***.***>
Sent: Monday, September 20, 2021 7:49 AM
To: PowerShell/PowerShell ***@***.***>
Cc: Subscribed ***@***.***>
Subject: Re: [PowerShell/PowerShell] Get-Item for a file sometimes returns a DirectoryInfo object (#16124)


Can you please remind me where to get it? I keep forgetting...

—
You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/16124#issuecomment-922651572>, or unsubscribe<https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABLIQTQ6VUWNTHDAO6OVKLLUC3DOJANCNFSM5ELENMOA>.
Triage notifications on the go with GitHub Mobile for iOS<https://apps.apple.com/app/apple-store/id1477376905?ct=notification-email&mt=8&pt=524675> or Android<https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.github.android&referrer=utm_campaign%3Dnotification-email%26utm_medium%3Demail%26utm_source%3Dgithub>.

> From: Stéphane BARIZIEN ***@***.***> Sent: Monday, September 20, 2021 7:49 AM To: PowerShell/PowerShell ***@***.***> Cc: Subscribed ***@***.***> Subject: Re: [PowerShell/PowerShell] Get-Item for a file sometimes returns a DirectoryInfo object (#16124) Can you please remind me where to get it? I keep forgetting... — You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<[#16124 (comment)](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/16124#issuecomment-922651572)>, or unsubscribe. Triage notifications on the go with GitHub Mobile for iOS or Android. ???
GitHub
Build software better, together
GitHub is where people build software. More than 65 million people use GitHub to discover, fork, and contribute to over 200 million projects.

> latest _daily_ PowerShell 7.2 build

Yes I can 😥

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12860484/133969904-ae2a18e4-9ce4-4603-bfbc-2d9d4389ec6b.png)
Thanks! I think it is Samba issue.
How can I help debug / analyze this?
Try using Procmon, see what is returned when the file is queried?
Very good suggestion, how come I didn't think of it?

Just captured a ProcMon trace. For some reason the failure occurred right away, at the first call to the `ProcessFile` function:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12860484/134033605-2d5fc9c2-778d-42c7-93d9-d259f868e87f.png)

I do see `QueryNetworkOpenInformationFile` returning "D" as `FileAttributes`:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12860484/134034016-d40e93d5-2ada-4b40-959e-5f257ff50320.png)

The plot thickens:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12860484/134035955-b5f730df-759f-4321-b048-ae7ff902b67b.png)

This is what I see on the Ubuntu side of the fence:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12860484/134036011-c9a9c38d-f5a4-407c-a80c-f0d6b02cc7fd.png)
Based on the results, it appears that the problem is with Samba occasionally returning incorrect data?

Looks like it indeed... I need to find out how to investigate _that_, using methods that are as close as possible to the network redirector...

Maybe I should first write a small C++ piece of code invoking Win32 APIs...

Something is really weird: if I run `get-item -literalpath '\\pnjnas\usbdisk1\sto\LATITUDE7400\Data\C\Users\sto\OneDrive\Images\edit\2015\02\15\IMG_0751 (2021_03_14 18_18_52 UTC).JPG'` from an interactive PowerShell prompt, I **always** get a `FileInfo`:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12860484/134321498-047d5d18-cdf2-4db2-92ba-161bfbc8427f.png)


`stat` from WSL2 also says it's a file:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12860484/134321375-3689ccdf-8442-48d5-9149-68e754a1e170.png)

Sniffed with Wireshark: they're only one request while the repro script runs (caching?), and the return from Samba seems correct:


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12860484/134347727-1f1bedc0-7cb8-46fb-bb3b-83a574bbd989.png)

FYI I'm moving to debugging this within PowerShell itself. I've built the latest code (`7.2.0-preview.10-57-g7cf1ef8c8599a90cd9579c7bb7b7676e097c4938`) and will try to understand what's going on when **only one** of the `Get-Item` invocations during the execution of my repro script returns a `DirectoryInfo`.

@SteveL-MSFT: any advice?

Try changing the check in your script to this (**not** running it interactively, change it in the script):

```powershell
$attrib = [IO.FileInfo]::new($thePath).Attributes
$attrib -ne -1 -and $attrib.HasFlag([IO.FileAttributes]::Directory)
```

That's basically all the provider is doing, but still worth checking.

- If that returns the same thing, try it in C#
- If in C# it returns the same, try writing a C++ app that calls [`glibc!stat`](https://www.man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/stat.2.html) and tests `(statbuf.st_mode & S_IFMT) == S_IFDIR` (seems like all that dotnet/runtime does, see [here](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/ce99c5658cc8c6ef426f54864d394ba443820840/src/libraries/System.Private.CoreLib/src/System/IO/FileStatus.Unix.cs#L371-L372) and [here](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/ce99c5658cc8c6ef426f54864d394ba443820840/src/libraries/Native/Unix/System.Native/pal_io.c#L192))

Though tbh it kind of seems a bit like a race condition so adjusting the timing by moving the faster languages may not actually definitively prove where the problem is.

> My gut feeling is there's some code that gets the attributes for the file's parent, and that sometimes this ends up in the object returned by `Get-Item` instead of the child's attributes.

Hmm I'm confused, don't the results show the same problem present? Or was that mistakenly old results?

Yes the new test shows the same problem. 

And indeed, there's no `Get-Item` involved anymore. 

So yes I mixed up my new results and my older hypothesis. 
Sorry for that.
I think the next step will be to write something in C# that reproduces "exactly" what the PowerShell script does, complete with searching for files in the tree etc.
I think to close the issue until we get more information.
This issue has been marked as answered and has not had any activity for **1 day**. It has been closed for housekeeping purposes.
Still haven't found bandwidth to write the C# test thingie, but FWIW the issue is still present in PowerShell 7.3.0-preview.1
Intrigue! 😺
